title: Present Tense
content:
Written by Mike ᎩᏳᎦ White

I. Present Tense Stem

Find ᏨᏔᏗᎭ tsvtadiha in this passage from page 1 of Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-02-23.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎡᏥ ᎪᏪᎵ ᎥᏥᎾᎩ ᏦᏪᎳᏅᎯ ᎤᏙᎯᏳ ᎬᏯᎵᎮᎵᏥᏏ ᎠᎴᏋ ᏥᎬᏯᏛᎬᎦ ᎠᏏᏋ ᏙᎯᏋ ᎨᏒ ᏨᏔᏗᎭ.

Etsi, goweli vtsinagi tsowehlanvhi. Udohiyu gvyalihelitsisi alequv tsigvyadvgvga asiquv tohiquv gesv tsvtadiha.

‘Mother, I received your letter. I am very grateful for this that I heard from you and that you say you are well.’

ᏨᏔᏗᎭ tsvtadiha ‘that you say’ is an example of the Cherokee present tense. The author uses the present tense in the above example because he is writing the letter right now, and he has Dollie’s letter right in front of him to refer to, as if she is speaking to him right now.

Focus Vocabulary

ᏏᏲ siyo ‘hello’
ᎣᏏᏊᏧ osiquutsu ‘How are you? (Are you just fine?)’
ᏙᎯᏧ tohitsu ‘How are you? (Are you at peace?)’
ᎣᏏᏊ osiquu ‘It’s just fine.’ (Response to ‘How are you?’)
ᏙᎯᏊ tohiquu ‘It’s just peaceful.’ (response to ‘How are you?’)
ᏂᎯᎾ nihina ‘How about you?’
ᎣᏏᏊ ᏥᏕᎾᏓᎪᏩᏔ osiquu tsidenadagowata
 ‘It’s nice to see you.’
ᏙᎾᏓᎪᎲᎢ donadogohvi ‘Goodbye.’ (to one person)
ᏙᏓᏓᎪᎲᎢ dodadagohvi ‘Goodbye.’ (to more than one person)
ᏣᏓᎦᏎᏍᏕᏍᏗ tsadagsesdesdi ‘Take care!’
ᏩᏙ wado ‘Thank you.’
ᎭᏩ hawa ‘You’re welcome.’
ᎠᏗᎭ adiha ‘he/she/it is saying’
ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ aliheliga ‘he/she/it is glad/thankful’
ᎦᏙ ᎤᏍᏗ
 gado usdi
 ‘What?’/‘What is it?’

ᏨᏔᏗᎭ tsvtadiha is a form of one of the most common verbs in Cherokee:

ᎠᏗᎭ     adiha     ‘he/she/it is saying’

The present tense stem of ᎠᏗᎭ adiha is /-adih-/. Most resource materials, however, do not use the stem to identify verbs. Verb stems, detached from their pronoun prefixes and tense indicators never occur in the language. For this reason, while a verb stem seen by itself is useful in teaching materials, it has no meaning on its own.

Instead, the third person singular form (he/she/it) of the present tense is used as the dictionary entry form of the Cherokee verb. The present progressive (-ing form, ongoing in the present) of the English verb is usually used to translate the Cherokee present tense, which is used specifically to tell what is happening right now.

Here are some examples of ᎠᏗᎭ adiha in the present tense. Notice that the verb always appears ‘fully outfitted’ with prefixes to indicate, among other things, the subject of the verb, and a suffix to indicate the ongoing present tense:

ᏨᏔᏗᎭ      tsvtadiha             ‘as you are saying’ (Letters to Duncan: 1951-02-07 and 1951-04-04)

ᏥᎦᏗᎭ        tsigadiha             ‘as I am saying’ (Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-02-20)

ᎦᏗᎠ              gadi’a                    ‘I am saying’ (Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-02-23)

ᏱᎦᏗᎭ          yigadiha             ‘I am not saying’ (Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-02-20)

ᏦᏍᏓᏗᎭ     tsosdadiha         ‘what we two are saying’ (Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-04-10)

Notice how all the forms end in –a, the most common present tense ending in Cherokee. Cherokee uses the present tense to talk about experiences and actions happening right now.

Exercise

Refer to the examples above to match each phrase with the correct translation.

1. As I am saying Ꭰ. Tsosdadiha
2. As you are saying Ꭱ. Gadi’a
3. I am saying Ꭲ. Yigadiha
4. What we two are saying Ꭳ. Tsvtadiha
5. I am not saying Ꭴ. Tsigadiha

Find ᎦᏗᎠ gadi’a in this passage from page 2 of Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-02-23.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎢᏴᏓᎭᏗᏃᎾ ᎾᏍᏋ ᎢᎬᏌ ᎢᏓᏓᏅᏕᏍᎬ ᏱᏂᏓᏛᏁᎭ ᎠᏴ ᎢᏗᏣᎳᎩᎭ Ᏺ ᎠᏆᏦᏍᏓᏏ ᎢᏗᏣᎳᎩᏯ ᎦᏗᎠ ᎠᎩᏰᎸᎭ.

Iyvdahadinona, nasquv igvsa idadanvdesgv yinidadvneha ayv Iditsalagiha, yo! Aquatsosdasi, ‘Iditsalagiya’ gadi’a agiyelvha.

‘Sometimes, we in Cherokees [sic] should also do what we are thinking. Oh, I made a mistake, I meant to say ‘we full-blooded Cherokees.”

In order to say ‘I meant to say,’ the author literally writes in Cherokee, ‘I am saying I mean.’ The reference is to the preceding sentence, in which the author mistakenly writes ᎢᏗᏣᎳᎩᎭ iditsalagiha instead of ᎢᏗᏣᎳᎩᏯ iditsalagiya.

Look at the following example from page 1 of Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-04-01.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎥᏝᏗᎾ ᎡᎶᎯᏋ ᎡᎯ ᏱᎦᏗᎭ.

Vtladina elohiquv ehi yigadiha.

I’m really not saying just worldly things.

a. Write the form of ᎠᏗᎭ adiha that you find and its translation.

b. Look again at the above sentence in Cherokee. What is different about where the verb occurs in the Cherokee sentence as opposed to the English?

II. Set A Pronoun Prefixes

Below are the Set A Personal Pronoun Prefixes. The first prefix given for each person is used when the stem begins with a consonant, the second one when the stem begins with a vowel. The two are separated by a comma. Don’t worry about memorizing this chart now! It is provided only for reference.

person singular dual plural
1st tsi-, g- inclusive ini-, in-
 idi-, id-
exclusive osdi-, osd-
 otsi-, ots-
2nd hi-, h- sdi-, sd-
 itsi-, its-
3rd (a-, ga-, ka-), (g-, -) ani-, an- ani-, an-

The pronoun prefixes for 3rd person singular Set A verbs can vary a lot from verb to verb, as you can see. The first set of three prefixes in parentheses (a-, ga-, ka-) appear on verb stems that begin with a consonant. When the verb begins with a vowel, the 3rd person singular may take a g- prefix, or no prefix at all, like the verb we will look at now.

ᎠᏗᎭ adiha ‘he/she/it is saying’ is a Set A verb and so takes Set A pronoun prefixes in the present tense.  Here are the present tense forms of ᎠᏗᎭ adiha conjugated with the Set A pronoun prefixes, and translation:

ᎠᏗᎭ     adiha     ‘he/she/it is saying’

person singular dual plural
1st ᎦᏗᎠ

gadi’a

‘I am saying’

 inclusive ᎢᎾᏗᎭ

inadiha

‘you and I are saying’

 ᎢᏓᏗᎭ

idadiha

‘we all are saying’
exclusive ᎣᏍᏓᏗᎭ

osdadiha

‘he/she and I are saying’

 ᎣᏣᏗᎭ

otsadiha

‘they and I are saying’
2nd ᎭᏗᎭ

hadiha

‘you are saying’

 ᏍᏓᏗᎭ

sdadiha

‘you two are saying’

 ᎢᏣᏗᎭ

itsadiha

‘you all are saying’
3rd ᎠᏗᎭ

adiha

‘he/she/it is saying’

 ᎠᎾᏗᎭ

anadiha

‘they are saying’

 ᎠᎾᏗᎭ

anadiha

‘they are saying’

Following a pattern among many Cherokee verbs that have an h sound in the stem, the first person singular gadi’a drops the h sound and replaces it with a **glottal stop**, indicated with an apostrophe.

Cherokee does not have separate pronoun prefixes for ‘he,’ ‘she,’ or ‘it.’ The gender of the person doing the action depends on context.

Fun fact! Cherokee distinguishes between forms of ‘we’ depending on whether the person being spoken to is **included** or **excluded**. See further discussion below.

Notes on Pronunciation

 The glottal stop is one feature of Cherokee pronunciation that requires practice. It is a catch in the voice, like what we hear in the English word “reentry” just before the second syllable. Sometimes the glottal stop in phonetic transcription is represented with a colon [:], sometimes with the international phonetic symbol [ʔ], but here, we will use the apostrophe [‘].

ᎦᏗᎠ             gadi’a                 ‘I am saying’

ᎦᎵᎡᎵᎦ     gali’eliga     ‘I am glad/thankful’

Notice that glottal stops are not indicated in the syllabary. The correct pronunciation of each word needs to be learned individually.

III. Another Verb

A common verb that is conjugated like ᎠᏗᎭ adiha is:

ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ     aliheliga     ‘he/she is glad/thankful’

person singular dual plural
1st ᎦᎵᎵᎦ

gali’eliga

‘I am glad’

 inclusive ᎢᎾᎵᎮᎵᎦ

inaliheliga

‘you and I are glad’

 ᎢᏓᎵᎮᎵᎦ

idaliheliga

‘we all are glad’
exclusive ᎣᏍᏓᎵᎮᎵᎦ

osdaliheliga

‘he/she and I are glad’

 ᎣᏣᎵᎮᎵᎦ

otsaliheliga

‘they and I are glad’
2nd ᎭᎵᎮᎵᎦ

haliheliga

‘you are glad’

 ᏍᏓᎵᎮᎵᎦ

sdaliheliga

‘you two are glad’

 ᎢᏣᎵᎮᎵᎦ

itsaliheliga

‘you all are glad’
3rd ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ

aliheliga

‘he/she/it is glad’

 ᎠᎾᎵᎮᎵᎦ

analiheliga

‘they are glad’

 ᎠᎾᎵᎮᎵᎦ

analiheliga

‘they are glad’

Don’t worry about memorizing all these forms. For now, let’s just focus on the three singular forms and the 3rd person plural of ᎠᏗᎭ adiha and ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ aliheliga.

ᎦᏗᎠ             gadi’a                I am saying

ᎭᏗᎭ            hadiha               you are saying

ᎠᏗᎭ            adiha                  he/she/it is saying

ᎠᎾᏗᎭ         anadiha            they are saying

ᎦᎵᎡᎵᎦ        gali’eilga           I am glad

ᎭᎵᎮᎵᎦ         haliheliga         you are glad

ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ        aliheliga           he/she/it is glad

ᎠᎾᎵᎮᎵᎦ     analiheliga       they are glad

Find the form of ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ aliheliga in this passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-04-04.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎭᏍᎩᏂ ᎦᎵᎮᎵᎬ ᎾᎦᏲᏢ ᎠᎩᎷᎸ ᎠᏂ ᎾᏋ ᎠᎩᏅᎪᎢᏍᏗᎢ.

Hasgini galiheligv nagayotlv agilulv ani, naquv aginvgoisdii.

‘But I am glad that I have such a short time left, then I will be getting out.’

a. Write the form and its translation.

b. Because Cherokee has always primarily been a spoken language, spelling often varies from community to community. What is different about the way the word is spelled in the chart as opposed to the letter?

Find the form of ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ aliheliga in this passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-02-11.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

Pronunciation: Tones and Syllable Length

 Tones and cadence (the pace of pronouncing each syllable in a word) are critical for Cherokee pronunciation. As you learn each new word in Cherokee, it is important to try to imitate as closely as possible the pronunciation of first language speakers, as it will determine whether or not what you are saying will be understood!

There are four basic tones in Cherokee and three gliding tones. Many sources use a method of indicating a word’s critical tones using numbers in superscript:

1-lowfall           3-high           23-rising           43-high fall

2-neutral           4-highrise       32-falling

Syllables will either be short or long, long syllables extending twice the amount of time as short syllables. A short syllable in many sources is indicated with an underdot. Here are two examples of words in syllabary with different meanings depending on pronunciation:

ᎠᎹ      a3ma             salt                               ᎠᏚ      ga4du             bread

ᎠᎹ      a2ma             water                           ᎠᏚ      ga2du3           on top of

“Salt” is pronounced with the first syllable being long and high. “Water” is pronounced with the first syllable short and neutral. “Bread” is spoken with a long, highrise first syllable, while “on top” is pronounced with a short, neutral first syllable and high, long final syllable.

It may seem overwhelming to a new student of Cherokee, but it is not necessary to memorize the tone markers for each word. Simply listen closely and repeat as faithfully as you can to what you hear. Eventually you will begin to recognize patterns as you become more and more familiar with the sounds of the language.

2The 3rd person singular pronoun prefix for verb stems that begin with a consonant, or with the a- sound will take the pronoun prefix u- , and drop the a-. Stems that begin with a vowel other than a- will take uw-.

title: Cherokee Sovereignty
content:
Written by Ben Frey

The following collection of governance documents offers a unique insight into the complexities of cultural identity and adaptation among Giduwa (Cherokee) people. These documents were created at a time when the Giduwa community was seeking ways to make themselves legible and understood by outsiders while simultaneously remaining true to themselves and their ancient traditions. Even the spelling of their name – whether Keetoowah, Giduwa, or Cherokee – reflects this tumultuous period of negotiation. The creation of a U.S-style governance structure represented a precarious balance, serving as both an unconventional container for Giduwa ways of being as well as a bridge for communicating with large external institutions. In order to have a voice in government policy decisions that affected their community, they had to represent themselves within a similar constitutional structure, but they had to do so without sacrificing the very nature of who they were.

At the same time, the development of these governance documents reflects a deeper internal process of re-examination and re-negotiation of traditional social mores and institutions. Drafting such documents meant that Giduwas had to adapt to a more centralized, hierarchical way of administration that was not traditionally a part of their culture while thinking carefully about which aspects of the culture they would enshrine within that framework.

Ultimately, the community sought to balance the way they were perceived with the way they truly were. We see them here asking themselves if they should use the language of the documents to describe themselves as accurately as possible, or yield to governmental structures and bureaucracy that did not support their integrity. They were forced to ask themselves if could they show up in a way the United States and its government agencies could comprehend, but maintain their sense of themselves. Their solution to adopt certain structures while operating and interpreting them to maintain Giduwa values reflects a deep resiliency and ingenuity within the community.

This process of negotiation and adaptation linked Giduwa people with many other nations who contended with similar circumstances, reconciling central concepts of cultural integrity with an ability to grow and change. By and large, the struggle of such communities reflects the will of Indigenous people to survive in the face of overwhelming odds. Such struggles also represent the particular resilience of Giduwa people in their willingness to adapt and change to communicate with external powers while remaining true to the core of their identity.

title: Speeches
content:
Written by Ben Frey

These speeches offer a glimpse into the richness and breadth of Cherokee oratory. They show a striving for cohesion in the Giduwa community and maintenance of cultural and spiritual traditions. The speeches range from warnings about cultural trends endangering the community to memories of spirit journeys and histories of how communities were named. Elders gathered to tell stories to younger generations and teach them Giduwa lifeways. Close friends reference and characterize prominent figures as the speeches reveal the inner workings of Giduwa people's souls.

title: Stories as Knowledge
content:
Written by Rachel C. Jackson

To respect the power their stories hold, Cherokee people regard words themselves as the medicine that makes the world. Breath expelled from our bodies animates the words we speak into the air. These words reflect what we carry inside of us and replicate it outside. Words shape perceptions, influencing our thoughts and the thoughts of others, the choices we make, and the actions we take to construct the reality around us. Words matter. It is our responsibility to use them wisely, knowing we inhale back into our bodies the same air into which we speak.

Stories contain the substance and sustenance of Cherokee life. This collection asserts the strength of the oral tradition through which Keetoowah ways endured, the foundation upon which they continue to rely even as these stories now reside in a digital archive. Before being transcribed into the syllabary, stories persisted for centuries via memory and the spoken word. This practice and its success defy the Western literacy standards imposed during colonization, those that privilege text, print, now pixels, and the complex technologies that produce them with the goal of housing knowledge beyond the body and separating us from who we are. Cherokees have remained resilient through, with, and because of these stories.

The stories herein acknowledge the story's teller and end with a gentle, encouraging command to remember them and share them. Cherokees share stories at the right time with the right people for the right reasons. Often a story appears wanting to be told in a particular situation and for a particular listener or listeners who might benefit. Storytellers rarely explain why a story is told, leaving that work respectfully to the story and the audience. The responsible recipient begins a relationship with the story, one that deepens over time. The story pulses within as its meaning arises, surfacing again in new contexts and ever-changing. Carried upon breath, it passes again to another, always with tribute to the source from whom it was received.

The Willie Jumper Stories permit a pristine encounter with story as the vital center of Cherokee identity. Spanning four decades before and after the 20th century's turn, these accounts depict individual lives and bestow traditional knowledge, blending them together and keeping both people and traditions alive. Elders, relatives, friends, places and communities, beliefs and practices move within these stories as one, illustrating the profound coherence Cherokee cultural integrity entails. Storytelling remembers the past in the present, advancing it for the future. Memory is a vessel and sharing is a sacred obligation.

title: Syllabary
content:
Print Module

1. Introduction

Learning to read and write syllabary is part of becoming well-rounded in the Cherokee language. It also opens the door to understanding old documents, and is thus a window into the past. Every document here is a treasury of Cherokee words and their usage as well as culture. Being able to read and interpret documents is crucial to the survival of the language.

When doing the exercises, also write them out by hand. Typing in syllabary is fun and a great way to use Cherokee across social media. It's also important to be comfortable with typing up documents or lessons to share. But writing Cherokee words by hand is one of the best ways to help you learn and retain them. Researchers have found that writing by hand uses several different parts of the brain together, which helps to cement new material in your memory. When you write, you feel the paper, you feel the pen or pencil, and you call up the shape of the syllabary character from memory, or use a chart to follow. Your mind directs your hand and your fingers to create the shape.

You are involved directly, and your writing is personal and unique to you. When you type a syllabary character, on the other hand, all you have to do is recognize the correct key and press it. The image is made without any involvement or thought. Anyone could press the same key and make the identical character show up on the screen or paper. It is completely impersonal, and much less likely to be retained in your memory.

Don't rush, but instead write the words out carefully and keep them in a notebook or portfolio for future reference. You will be improving your syllabary and vocabulary at the same time.

2. Recognizing Intrusive H

Next, open the pronunciation tab and notice the phonetics. Write ᎠᏅᏱ again,
with the correct phonetics and the meaning, as in the example above.

You will have noticed an "h" sound that wasn't written in the syllabary word. It is called an "intrusive h,"
sometimes referred to just as "unole," or air. You can't see an intrusive h when looking at syllabary characters, but you will learn where they belong by listening to speakers, and by paying attention to phonetics.

Whether a word has in intrusive h or not can affect its meaning. For example, ᎪᏪᎵᎠ can be spelled phonetically:

go-hwe-li-a 'He or she is writing it,' or go-we-li-a 'I am writing it'

4. Reading

'When I travelled through the Cherokee Nation, during the months of January and February, 1828, before the press was set up, or any printing had been executed in the alphabet of Guess, I was informed in many parts of the nation, that almost all the young and middle aged men could read in that alphabet, with many of the old men, and of the women, and of the children. One very old Cherokee man came to a place where I spent a night, to obtain a sheet of paper, for the purpose of writing a letter to a friend, residing among that portion of the tribe west of the Mississippi. When asked if he could write, he replied that he could not, but that his son had learned the new letters and could write what he told him. A small full-Cherokee boy, who had been received into one of the schools from a very ignorant part of the nation, totally unacquainted with the English language, except that he was beginning to
learn the alphabet, was requested to read a few lines in the characters of Guess, that were printed in Boston merely as a specimen of the language. He read it correctly, and without hesitation.

'I frequently saw, as I rode from place to place, Cherokee letters painted or cut on the trees by the road side, on fences, houses, and often on pieces of bark or board, lying about the houses. The alphabet of Guess had never been taught in schools. The people have learned it from one another; and that too without books, or paper, or any of the common facilities for writing or teaching. They cut the letters, or drew them with a piece of coal, or with paint. Bark, trees, fences, the walls of houses &c. answered the purpose of paper or slates.'

'That the mass of a people, without schools or books, should by mutual assistance, without extraneous impulse or aid, acquire the art of reading, and that in a character wholly original, is, I believe, a phenomenon unexampled in modern times.'

Boudinot, E. "ART. V.–INVENTION OF A NEW ALPHABET." American Annals of
Education (1830-1839) 2 (1832): 174.

This module is intended to engage with language learners who are advanced in their understanding of Cherokee. The activities in this module will enhance a language learner’s capacity for identifying greetings, understanding word orders within a sentence, identifying metaphors in Cherokee, and understanding Cherokee humor. title: Verb Parts
content:
Written by Mike ᎩᏳᎦ White

I. Clitics: -Ꮷ -tsu and -Ꮚ -quu

Read the following line from Letter to Dollie Duncan: 1951-03-11.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎠᏴ ᎠᏴᏋ ᏃᏈᏏ. ᎾᏍᏋ ᏫᎬᏲᎵᎦᏓ ᎣᏏᏲ ᏙᎯᏨ.

Ayv, ayvquv, Noquisi, nasquv wigvyoligada, “Osiyo, tohitsv?”

Me, a prisoner, Star also greets you all, “Hello, are you well?

Do you see any words you recognize? Look at the last word ᏙᎯᏨ tohitsv ‘Are you well?’ This word is made up of a base word and the clitic -Ꮷ -tsu or here, -Ꮸ tsv:

Base word:     ᏙᎯ tohi     +      Clitic: -Ꮸ –tsv

The Cherokee language has a number of suffixes that perform their own special functions, such as to create transitions or ask questions. These special suffixes are called ‘clitics.’

The word ᏙᎯ tohi by itself means ‘calm,’ ‘peaceful’ or ‘at peace.’ The clitic -Ꮸ -tsv is a very common regional or speaker-specific variant of -Ꮷ -tsu. Together, ᏙᎯᏧ tohitsu literally means ‘Is it peaceful?’ but it is used to mean ‘Are you well?’ or loosely, ‘How are you?’ In a fuller sense, the word can mean, ‘Are you well? It appears you are, I have no reason to believe otherwise, so expect you to say yes!’

The clitic -Ꮷ –tsu is used to ask yes-or-no questions, primarily when a yes response is anticipated.

ᏆᎾ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ.       Quana tsaduliha.                  You want a peach.

ᏆᎾᏧ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ?    Quanatsu tsaduliha?               Do you want a peach?

It will almost always be attached to the end of the first word in the sentence, even if it means splitting a two-word compound.

ᎪᎯ ᎢᎦ ᏧᎾᎩᎶᏍᏗ.      Kohi iga Tsunagilosdi.              Today is Friday.

ᎪᎯᏧ ᎢᎦ ᏧᎾᎩᎶᏍᏗ?   Kohitsu iga Tsunagilosdi?            Is today Friday?

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-04-01.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᏗᎪᏍᏗ ᏅᏙᏓᏣᏗᏍᏗ ᏣᏗᎭ ᏞᏍᏗᏋ ᏅᏙᏓᏣᏛᎭ ᎨᏳᏁᎦ ᎣᎵᎦᏨ?

Digosdi nvdodatsadisdi tsadiha tlesdiquv nvdodatsadvha, Geyunega, olhgatsv?

Do not send the cigarettes that you said you would send, Ge-yu-ne-ga. Do you understand?

Which word has the clitic on the end, making it a yes-or-no question and what does the word mean?

The word ᎣᎵᎦᏨ oligatsv is a different way to write ᎰᎵᎦᏧ holhgatsu ‘Do you understand?’

Instead of -Ꮸ -tsv, for our exercises, we will be using -Ꮷ –tsu, the clitic as it appears in language resources commonly used today both by the **Cherokee Nation** and **EBCI** (Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians).

In order to make things more fun, let’s learn a few more common Cherokee names to use in our practice:

ᎧᎹᎹ Kamama Butterfly
ᏩᎴᎳ   Walela Hummingbird
ᏌᎶᎵ Saloli Squirrel
ᏙᏯᏂᏓ Doyanida Young Beaver
ᏧᎳ Tsula Fox
ᏲᎾ Yona Bear

Exercise: ᏙᎯᏧ? Tohitsu?

Making yes-or-no questions in Cherokee is easy! Add the clitic -Ꮷ –tsu to the following sentences to make them a question. Then, write what the question means in English. Follow the example:

Example:

ᏙᎯ. Tohi. It’s peaceful.            Tohitsu? Are you well?

  1. ᎣᏏᏊ. Osiquu. It’s just fine.                                                                                      
  2. ᏒᎦᏔ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ. Svgta tsaduliha. You want an apple.                                    
  3. ᏌᎶᎵ ᏏᏲ ᎠᏗᎭ. Saloli Siyo adiha. Saloli is saying hello.                           
  4. ᏲᎾ ᎪᎱᏍᏗ ᎤᏚᎵᎭ. Yona gohusdi uduliha. Yona wants something.     
  5. ᎰᎵᎦ. Holhga. You understand.                                                                   
  6. ᎭᎵᎮᎵᎦ. Haliheliga. You are glad.                                                                
  7. ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ. Aliheliga. He is glad.                                                                       
  8. ᏩᎴᎳ ᎤᏅᏔ. Walela unhta. Walela knows.                                                    
  9. ᏣᏅᏔ. Tsanhta. You know.                                                                       
  10. ᏧᎳ ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ. Tsula aliheliga. Tsula is glad.                                               

The clitic -Ꮚ –quu is used in conversational Cherokee to mean ‘just’:

ᎣᏏ          osi            fine

ᎣᏏᏊ     osiquu        just fine

Look at the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-02-07 and answer the questions below:

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎡᏥ, ᎪᏪᎵ ᎥᏥᎾᎩ ᏅᏓᏦᏪᎳᏅᎯ. ᎤᏣᏘᏋ ᎦᎵᎮᎵᎩ ᎠᏏᏋ ᏙᎯᏋ ᎨᏒ ᏨᏔᏗᎭ. ᎠᏴᏃ ᎨᏒ ᎾᏍᏋ ᎢᎬᏩᏍᏗᎭᏋ ᏙᎯ ᏓᎩᎩᏨᏁᎦ.

Etsi, goweli vtsinagi nvdatsowelanvhi. Utsatiquv galiheligi asiquv tohiquv gesv tsvtadiha. Ayvno gesv nasquv igvwasdihaquv tohi dagigitsvnega.

Mother, I have received your letter. I am really glad that you are still well, as you were saying. As for me, I am the same, still healthy from day to day.

a. Can you find the word that means ‘as you were saying’? Write it down:     

b. Find the two words that contain the word ‘it is peaceful’ and write them down:     

Just like with the clitic -Ꮷ -tsu, the writer uses the common variant -Ꮛ -quv instead of -Ꮚ –quu.

Notice the other words/phrases in the above passage that feature this clitic:

ᎤᏣᏘᏋ ᎦᎵᎮᎵᎩ…       Utsatiquv galiheligi…             I was just so glad…

ᎢᎬᏩᏍᏗᎭᏋ               igvwasdihaquv                      just the same

-Ꮚ –quu is a very conversational clitic, being used so often that it has become imbedded as a permanent fixture in many Cherokee words and expressions:

ᏏᏊ siquu (or asiquv) still, again
ᎣᏏᏊᏧ Osiquutsu? How are you?
ᎣᏏᏊ osiquu just fine
ᎢᏳᏍᏗᏊ iyusdiquu whatever
ᎰᏩᏊ howaquu well, okay
ᎾᏞᎬᏊ natlegvgwu soon

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-02-07. See how many places you can find the clitic -Ꮛ –quv.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎣᏩᏋ, ᎦᏂᎬᎦᏋ ᎦᏃᎮᏢᏗᎢ ᎨᏒᎢ. ᎠᏎ ᎤᏟᏍᏓᏋ ᏫᏥᏃᎯᏏ ᎥᎨᎳ ᏫᏨᏲᎵᎦᏋᏃ ᏂᎦᏓ ᏏᏓᏁᎸᎢ. ᎣᏏᏲ ᎢᎾ ᎬᎴᎢ ᎠᎴ ᎪᏪᎵᏋ ᎬᏗ. ᎠᏴ ᎠᎹ ᎥᏉᏪᎳᏏ, ᏄᏍᏛᏋ ᏂᏥᏪᏍᎬᎢ.

Owaquv, ganigvgaquv ganohetlvdii gesvi. Ase utlisdaquv witsinohisi vgela witsvyoligaquvno nigada sidanelvi. Osiyo ina gvlei ale goweliquv gvdi. Ayv Ama vquowelasi, nusdvquv nitsiwesgvi.

Ok, there’s just not much to talk about. Thought I would quickly just say hello to all my family. “Hello” from afar, and just by mail. This was written for me by A-ma, just as I said.

How many did you find?        

Exercise:

ᎦᏂᎬᎦ ganigvga  ‘there’s nothing’
ᎤᏟᏍᏓ utlisda ‘quickly’
ᏫᏨᏲᎵᎦ witsvyoliga ‘I greet you all’
ᎪᏪᎵ goweli ‘a letter’
ᏄᏍᏛ nusdv ‘what’ (subordinating conj.)
1. ᎰᏩᏊ howaquu Ꭰ. just quickly
2. ᏏᏊ siquu Ꭱ. just in a letter
3. ᎣᏏᏊ osiquu Ꭲ. well, okay
4. ᎢᏳᏍᏗᏊ iyusdiquu Ꭳ. just what, just as
5. ᎤᏣᏘᏊ utsatiquu Ꭴ. there is just nothing
6. ᎦᏂᎬᎦᏊ ganigvgaquu Ꭵ. just really (a lot)
7. ᎤᏟᏍᏓᏊ utlisdaquu Ꭶ. still, again
8. ᏫᏨᏲᎵᎦᏊ witsvyoligaquu Ꭷ. whatever

10. ᏄᏍᏛᏊ nusdvquu Ꭹ. just fine

II. Second Person Dual and Plural Forms

ᎭᏗᎭ hadiha ‘you are saying’ is used only for speaking to **one person**. Cherokee language uses different pronoun prefixes for ‘you’ when speaking to **two people** or to **three or more people**:

ᎦᏙ ᎤᏍᏗ ᎭᏗᎭ?                Gado usdi hadiha?               What are you (singular) saying?

ᎦᏙ ᎤᏍᏗ ᏍᏓᏗᎭ?             Gado usdi sdadiha?               What are you two saying?

ᎦᏙ ᎤᏍᏗ ᎢᏣᏗᎭ?            Gado usdi itsadiha?             What are you all saying?

Unless otherwise indicated, where ‘you’ appears by itself, the second person singular will be intended.

Exercise: 

Ask the following people, ‘What are you saying?’ and ‘Are you glad?’ based on the number of people you are speaking to:

  1. What are you (singular) saying?            
  2.  Are you (singular) glad?                            
  3. What are you two saying?                        
  4.  Are you two glad?                                       
  5. What are you all saying?                             
  6. Are you all glad?                                           

Here are the three second person forms of ᎤᏚᎵᎭ uduliha ‘he,she wants it’ and ᎤᏅᏔ unhta ‘he,she knows it.’

ᏣᏚᎵᎭ tsaduliha ‘you want it’ ᏣᏅᏔ tsanhta ‘you know it’
ᏍᏓᏚᎵᎭ sdaduliha ‘you two want it’ ᏍᏓᏅᏔ sdanhta ‘you two know it’
ᎢᏣᏚᎵᎭ itsaduliha ‘you all want it’ ᎢᏣᏅᏔ itsanhta ‘you all know it’

Exercise: 

You are giving one child a snack when another walks into the room. Change the following questions so you are asking two people:

  1. ᏒᎦᏔᏧ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ? Svgtatsu tsaduliha? Do you (singular) want an apple?

    (Do you two want an apple?)

  2. ᏗᎦᏛᏗᏧ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ? Digadvditsu tsaduliha? Do you (singular) want a pear?

    (Do you two want a pear?)

    Another child enters the room, so now there are three children wanting snacks:

  3. ᏆᏁᎾᏧ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ? Quanenatsu tsaduliha? Do you (singular) want a banana?

    (Do you all want a banana?)

  4. ᎤᏅᏗᏧ ᏣᏚᎵᎭ? Unvditsu tsaduliha? Do you (singular) want milk?

    (Do you all want milk?)

III. First Person Dual, Plural, Inclusive and Exclusive Forms

The Cherokee language differentiates among first person dual and plural, **inclusive** and **exclusive**. This means there are four different ways to translate the idea ‘we’:

ᎢᎾᏗᎭ          inadiha             we two, **you and I**, are saying

ᎣᏍᏓᏗᎭ     osdadiha          we two, **he (or she) and I**, are saying (**not you**)

ᎢᏓᏗᎭ          idadiha             we all, **including you**, are saying

ᎣᏣᏗᎭ        otsadiha           we, **they and I**, are saying (**not you**)

What do the two inclusive pronoun prefixes have in common?

What do the two exclusive pronoun prefixes have in common?

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

Adina vtla hia tsadanilosv oginadvganv yosdadiha, hiasgini osda getsadanvdi tsowelanv ugvwiyuha.

But we are not referring to the news that you were ill, but that you were in good health when you wrote the letter.

‘Adina vtla hia tsadanilosv oginadvganv yosdadiha,’ is literally translated, ‘But we are not saying when we heard you were sick.’

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎢᎦᏁᎳᏅᎯᏃ ᎣᏏ ᎤᏰᎸᏁᏍᏗ, ᎢᎸᎯᏳᏋ ᏂᎨᏒᎾ, ᎢᎬᏌ ᏗᏗᏱᎵ ᏕᏛᏗᏍᎬ ᏙᏓᎵᏃᎮᎸᎢ, ᎥᏝᏍᎩᏂ ᏱᎦᏅᏔ ᎢᏳᎯ ᎨᏒᎢ.

Iganelanvhino osi uyelvnesdi, ilvhiyuquv nigesvna, igvsa didiyili dedvdisgv dodalinohelvi, vtlasgini yiganhta iyuhi gesvi.

title: Verb Tenses
content:
Written by Mike ᎩᏳᎦ White

I. Introduction to Aspect Stems

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-04-04 (DD9):

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎢᎬᏯᏗᏢ ᏕᎦᏍᏓᏰᏨᏥᏙᎣᎢ ᏴᏫ ᎨᏒ ᎤᏁᏓᏍᏗᎢ ᎠᏎᏃ ᏞᎦᏋ ᎨᎭ ᎨᎵᏍᎪ.Igvyaditlv degasdayetsvtsidooi, yvwi gesv unedasdii, asehno tlegaquv geha gelisgo.

I stomp around in the way, where people walk, but I think I will live a short time.

How is the verb ᎨᎵᏍᎪ gelisgo ‘I think’ different from the form of the verb you learned in Module 3 for ‘I think’?   

Cherokee has quite a versatile system for building tenses. It is **VERY** different from the English system of modals, helping verbs and participles to indicate tense, mood and voice. Most Cherokee verbs have five **aspect stems,** base forms that indicate some characteristic of the action being described, to which an ending will be attached. For the verb ᎡᎵᎠ eli’a ‘he/she thinks so’ you have already learned the **present continuous (ongoing)** aspect stem and the present tense ending:

ᎡᎵᎠ    eli’a    ‘he/she thinks so’

Pronoun Prefix Present Continuous Aspect Stem Ending
– eli’ -a

In contrast, the use of the **immediate aspect stem** indicates that the action happened just now, or should happen immediately, relative to the Cherokee idea of ᎪᎯ kohi “the current moment” which can last from a few minutes to several hours, but is **not** happening right now. So the immediate aspect stem will be used to form the immediate past and immediate command forms of a verb.

ᏏᏲ ᎠᏗᎭ.  Siyo adiha.  He is saying hello.
ᏏᏲ ᎠᏓ.  Siyo ada.  He said hello (just now).
ᎠᎦᏍᎦ.  Agasga.  It is raining.
ᎠᎦᎿ.
  Agahna.
  It rained (just now).

While there may be observable patterns to how the stems change from one tense to another, there are no universal rules governing these changes. That is why Cherokee grammar identifies each verb as having five distinct stems.

Here are the **aspect stems** and the tenses formed from each. The tense covered in modules 1-3 are bolded in red, and the tense we will cover now is **bolded in yellow**:

Aspect Stem Tenses Formed from Stem
✔ Modules 1-3: Present Continuous Aspect Present Tense
Completive Aspect Remote Past
Completive Future
Future Imperative
⇒ Module 4: Incompletive Aspect Present Habitual
Progressive/Habitual Past
Incompletive Future Imperative
Immediate Aspect Immediate Command
Immediate Past
Infinitive/Deverbal Aspect Infinitive

A dictionary entry for a verb will include all five aspect stems. Here is a sample dictionary entry for ᎡᎵᎠ eli’a ‘he/she thinks so.’ The forms covered in previous modules are **bolded in red**, the one we are currently studying is **bolded in yellow**. Notice how the stems can differ, and how the given example forms of the verb are translated:

                                       Modules 1-3                                                                                            Module 4

Can you recognize which forms of ᎡᎵᎠ eli’a **use the Set A prefixes and which use Set B?** Write each form from the middle row in the appropriate column:

Forms with Set A pronoun prefixes Forms with Set B pronoun prefixes
ᎡᎵᎠ     eli’a
ᎨᎵᎠ     gelia
ᎡᎵᏍᎪᎢ     elisgoi
ᎮᎳ     hela

Don’t worry about learning all of the aspect stems at once! Right now, just focus on the forms of the **habitual tense** for the verbs we have learned so far.

II. Incompletive Aspect Stem and Present Habitual Tense

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-02-20 (DD7).

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᏚᏳᎪᏛᏋ ᎨᏒ ᎬᏆᎴᏂᏗ ᏱᎩ, ᏰᎵᏋ ᎪᎱᏍᏗ ᎦᎦᏥᏍᏕᏡᏗ ᏱᏂᎦᎩ ᎢᎸᏢ ᏧᎾᏁᏡᏗ ᎤᎾᏓᏡᎬᎢ. ᎢᎨᎵᏍᎪ ᎢᏴᏓᎭᎯ.Duyugdvquv gesv gvqualenidi yigi, yeliquv gohusdi gagatsisdetludi yinigagi ilvtlv tsunanetludi unadatlugvi. Igelisgo iyvdahahi.

If I can begin in the right way, I would be able to help a Christian group somewhere, in some way with all that I can do. That is what I think sometimes.

Write the two words that make the sentence: ‘That is what I think sometimes.’    

The word ᎢᎨᎵᏍᎪ igelisgo is constructed as follows:

         i-                      preprominal prefix (ITER1) meaning ‘**again**’

         g-                     Set A first person singular pronoun prefix ‘I’

         -elisg-                 **incompletive stem** ‘think’

         -o                        **habitual tense ending**

The habitual tense ending is -o, or alternatively -o’i. The optional -i addition to the ending provides sometimes a sense of focus or pause, like a comma, or finality, like a period.

The use of the **incompletive aspect stem** will indicate that the action is repeated, happening **habitually or regularly** over a period of time. The **present habitual tense** will be used to show actions or states of being that occur habitually but are not necessarily happening right now. When translating into English, the words ‘**often**’ or ‘**always**’ can be used to distinguish it from the **ongoing present tense** for verbs that do not regularly appear in the –ing form in English.

                                                            Present Tense 

ᎠᏗᎭ  adiha  ‘he/she is saying’
ᎤᏚᎵᎭ  uduliha  ‘he/she wants it’
ᎡᎵᎠ  eli’a  ‘he/she thinks so’
ᎤᏅᏔ
   unhta    
  ‘he/she knows it’
ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ  aliheliga  ‘he/she is happy’ 
ᏄᏍᏓ
  nusda
  ‘it is’

                                                Present Habitual Tense

ᎠᏗᏍᎪᎢ  adisgo’i  ‘he/she says’
ᎤᏚᎵᏍᎪᎢ  udulisgo’i   ‘he/she often, always wants it’
ᎡᎵᏍᎪᎢ  elisgo’i  ‘he/she often, always thinks so’ 
ᎤᏅᏙᎢ  unhto’i    
  ‘he/she often, always knows it’
ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎪᎢ     aliheligo’i   ‘he/she is often, always happy’  
ᎨᏐᎢ  geso’i
  ‘it often, always is’

Notice that some verbs “recycle” their present tense stem for the habitual tense, while others have a modified incompletive stem.

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-04-10 (DD5).

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎣᎩᎾᎵᏍᏓᏗ ᎠᎾᏗᏍᎪᎢ ᎨᎵᎭ.Oginalisdaydi anadisgoi geliha.

I think they say it about how we eat.

What habitual tense form do you see in the example above? What does it mean? What verb does it come from?     

Exercise

Change the present tense verbs in the following sentences to the **habitual tense**.

  1. ᎺᎵ ᎠᎵᎮᎵᎦ. Meli aliheliga.  
  2. ᏗᏂᏲᏟ ᎧᎵᏎᏥ ᏚᎾᏚᎵᎭ. Diniyotli kalisetsi dunaduliha.  
  3. ᎣᏍᏓ ᏄᏍᏓ ᏙᏱᏗᏝ. Osda nusda doyiditla.  
  4. ᎭᎵᎮᎵᎦᏧ? Haliheligatsu?  
  5. ᏣᏅᏔᏧ? Tsanvtatsu?  

III. ᎤᏬᏚᎯ ᎨᏐᎢ. Uwoduhi gesoi. It’s always beautiful.

Ed Fields uses the following example in his Cherokee lessons:

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᏚᏂᏅᏗ ᎧᎸ ᎤᏬᏚᎯ ᎨᏐᎢ.Duninhdi kalv uwoduhi gesoi.

October is always beautiful.

What habitual tense verb do you see?

The verbs that describe the weather also have their forms in the habitual tense to talk about how weather always, often, or usually is.

                      Present Tense 

ᎤᏴᏜ  uhyvdla   ‘it’s cold’
ᎠᎦᏍᎦ  agasga  ‘it’s raining’ 
ᎠᎦᎵᎭ  agaliha  ‘it’s sunny’
ᎤᎦᎾᏩ  uganawa   ‘it’s warm’
ᎤᏗᏞᎦ  uditlega  ‘it’s hot’
ᎤᎶᎩᎳ  ulogila  ‘it’s cloudy’
ᎦᎳᎪᎰᏍᎦ  galogohosga 
ᎦᏍᏗᏬᎣᏍᎦ  gasdiwoosga
ᎫᏘᎭ  gutiha  ‘it’s snowing’

                      Present Habitual Tense

ᎤᏴᏠᎢ  uhyvdloi   ‘it’s always cold’
ᎠᎦᏍᎪᎢ  agasgoi  ‘it (always) rains’ 
ᎠᎦᎵᏍᎪᎢ  agalisgoi  ‘it’s (always) sunny’
ᎤᎦᎾᏫ ᎨᏐᎢ  uganawi gesoi   ‘it’s (always) warm’
ᎤᏗᏞᎪᎢ  uditlegoi  ‘it’s (always) hot’
ᎤᎶᎩᎶᎢ   ulogiloi  ‘it’s (always) cloudy’ 
ᎦᎳᎪᎰᏍᎪᎢ  galagohosgoi  ‘the leaves (always) turn’ 
ᎦᏍᏗᏬᎣᏍᎪᎢ  gasdiwoosgoi  ‘the leaves (always) fall’
ᎫᏘᏍᎪᎢ   gutisgoi  ‘it (always) snows’

Notice again how the **incompletive stem** for some verbs will change, while others only change the ending to form the habitual tense.

title: Verbs In Cherokee
content:
Created by Mike ᎩᏳᎦ White

In this module, we will build on previous teachings to identify the basic forms of Cherokee verbs and how they work. Most Cherokee verbs have multiple parts, including prefixes (an affix placed before the stem of a word) and affixes (an additional element placed at the beginning or end of a root, stem, or word to modify its meaning), and they demonstrate different kinds of understandings for Cherokee speakers. Language learners will learn the different kinds of Cherokee verbs (Set A and Set B), how to conjugate two verbs using selected pronominal prefixes, and the use of one-verb suffixes or sentences. Access the Cherokee Verb modules below.

II. Clitic -ᏍᎪ -sgo and talking about weather

The clitic -ᏍᎪ -sgo (-s, -sk) in Cherokee is used to ask **yes or no questions when the speaker does not know what the answer will be**.

ᎠᎦᏍᎦ.                 Agasga.                 It is raining.

ᎠᎦᏍᎦᏍᎪ?         Agasgasgo?            Is it raining?

Regional dialects have different ways of shortening this clitic in spoken Cherokee:

Clitic -ᏍᎪ Western Eastern
Shortened Written Form -Ꮝ -ᏍᎪ
Shortened Spoken Form -s -sk

Eastern speakers report sometimes feeling a sense of incompleteness when they hear a Western speaker say ᎠᎦᏍᎦᏍ agasgas ‘Is it raining?’ because they are expecting to hear agasgask with the -k sound at the end!

The Dollie Duncan letters feature several conversational descriptions of weather:

(DD9) ᎤᏬᏚᎯ uwoduhi it is beautiful
(DD7) ᏙᏱ doyi outside
(DD4) ᎤᎶᎩᎳ ulogila it is cloudy
(DD7) ᏓᎦᏍᎦ dagasga it is raining (more than once)
(DD3) ᏓᎦᎾ dagahna it just now rained (more than once)
(DD9) ᎤᎦᎾᏂᏕᎾ ugahnanidena it is about to rain
(DD9) ᎤᎦᏅᏗᏱ ugahndiyi for it to rain
(DD3) ᎤᎦᎾᏫ uganawi warm weather, a warm day

Here are a few more useful words for describing the weather we will use for the next exercises:

ᎫᏘᎭ gutiha it’s snowing
ᏓᎫᏔᏂ dagutahni it’s going to snow
ᏍᏓᏱᎨ sdayige harder
ᎦᏲᏟ gayotli a little bit
ᎤᏴᏜ uhyvdla it’s cold
ᎡᎵᏊ eligwu enough

III. Building conversational words in Cherokee: Yeligayaquvsgo?

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-02-20.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎢᎸᎯᏳ ᎢᏴᎢ ᏎᎳᎻᏃ ᏰᎵᎦᏯᏋᏍᎪ ᎣᏏ ᎬᏰᎸᏗ ᏕᏣᏠᏍᎪ ᏕᏥᎳᏫᎩ?Ilvhiyu iyvi Selamihno, yeligayaquvsgo osi gvyelvdi detsatlosgo detsilawigi?

Whenever you have a service at Salem, do you have good meetings?

The word ᏰᎵᎦᏯᏋᏍᎪ yeligayaquvsgo is a good example of how **prefixes, infixes, and clitics** string together in Cherokee to create meaning and functionality:

y(i)-                 doubt, possibility, contrary to fact (Prefix)

–ya                 real, really (Infix)

-quv, -quu     just (Clitic)

-sgo, -s, -sk     yes or no question without prejudice (Clitic)

When you start putting them together with the verb stem, you get:

ᎡᎵᎠ eli’a he/she thinks so
ᏰᎵᎦ yeliga it is sufficient
ᎡᎵᏊ eligwu enough
ᏰᎵᏊ yeligwu can (do), maybe enough
ᏰᎵᎦᏯ yeligaya quite, well
ᏰᎵᎦᏯᏋ yeligayaquv just quite…
ᏰᎵᎦᏯᏋᏍᎪ ᎣᏏ yeligayaquvsgo osi Is it pretty good?

Finally, in context:

Yeligayaquvsgo osi gvyelvdi detsatlosgo?                  Are your meetings pretty good?

Match the following sentences with the English translation.

1. ᎤᎦᎾᏂᏕᎾᏍ ᎮᎵᎠ?Ugahnanidenas heli’a? Ꭰ. Is it raining hard?
2. ᏰᎵᎦᏯᏋᏍᎪ ᎣᏍᏓ ᏙᏱ?Yeligayaquvsgo osda doyi? Ꭱ. Do you think it’s enough?
3. ᎤᎪᏗᏓᏍ ᎠᎦᏍᎦ?Ugodidas agasga? Ꭲ. Do you think it’s going to snow?
4. ᎫᏘᎭᏍ ᏃᏊ?Gutihas noquu? Ꭳ. Did it rain a little bit?
5. ᏓᎦᎾᏂᏍ ᎠᎾᏗᎭ?Dagahnanis anadiha? Ꭴ. Do you think it’s about to rain?
6. ᏍᏓᏱᎨᏍ ᎫᏘᎭ?Sdayiges gutiha? Ꭵ. Is it snowing now?
7. ᎡᎵᏊᏍ ᎮᎵᎠ?Eliquus heli’a? Ꭶ. Is it pretty nice outside?
8. ᎤᎪᏗᏓᏍ ᏓᎫᏔᏂ ᎠᏗᎭ?Ugodidas dagutahni adiha? Ꭷ. Is he saying it’s going to snow a lot?
9. ᎦᏲᏟᏍ ᎠᎦᎾ?Gayotlis agahna? Ꭸ. Is it snowing harder?
10. ᏓᎫᏔᏂᏍ ᎮᎵᎠ?Dagutahnis heli’a? Ꭹ. Are they saying it’s going to rain?

**Matches**

1. Ꭴ (Do you think it’s about to rain?)

2. Ꭶ (Is it pretty nice outside?)

3. Ꭰ (Is it raining hard? - *Note: This likely means "Is it raining a lot/hard?"*)

4. Ꭵ (Is it snowing now? - *Note: noquu translates to 'now' or 'just'*) - *Mistake in question, likely "Is it snowing yet/now?"*

5. Ꭹ (Are they saying it’s going to rain?)

6. Ꭸ (Is it snowing harder?)

7. Ꭱ (Do you think it’s enough?)

8. Ꭷ (Is he saying it’s going to snow a lot?)

9. Ꭳ (Did it rain a little bit?)

10. Ꭲ (Do you think it’s going to snow?)

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-04-04 and write the vocabulary you recognize on the line.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎤᏙᎯᏳᏋᏗᎾ ᎤᎦᎾᏂᏕᎾ ᎤᎵᏏᏂᏗ ᎤᏚᎩᏋ ᎦᎬᏗ ᎤᎦᏅᏗᎢ ᎠᏗᎾ ᏑᎾᎴ ᎦᏄᎸ ᏓᏥᎦᎸᏏ ᎤᏙᎯᏳ ᎤᏬᏚᎯ ᏅᏓᎦᏥᏴᏁᎵ ᎨᎵᎭ.Udohiyuquvdina ugahnanidena. Ulisinidi. Udugiquv gagvdi uganvdii adina sunale ganulv datsigalvsi.Udohiyu uwoduhi nvdagatsiyvneli geliha.

It’s really about to rain. It’s almost dark. I was hoping it would rain. And so, tomorrow I will mow the grass. I think I am going to make it beautiful for them.

Write the vocabulary you recognize on the line.

Grammar note: The -i ending is one way that Cherokee forms **adjectives from verbs**.

ᎤᏴᏜ. Uhyvdla. ‘It is cold.’                       ᎤᏴᏟ uhyvdli ‘a cold day’

ᎤᎦᎾᏩ. Uganawa. ‘It is warm.’          ᎤᎦᎾᏫ uganawi ‘a warm day’

The adjective form of certain weather words can easily be combined with ᎨᏎᏍᏗ gesesdi ‘it will be’ or ᎨᏒᎢ gesvi ‘it was’ to talk about how the weather will be or how the weather was.

ᎤᏴᏟ ᎨᏎᏍᏗ.                  Uhydli gesesdi.                  ‘It will be cold.’

ᎤᎦᎾᏫᏋ ᎨᏒᎢ.               Uganawiquv gesvi.          ‘It was (just) warm.’

Dialect note: The Eastern dialect tends to avoid using the Ꮬ/Ꮭ dla/tla sounds in Cherokee (while not omitting them entirely) often using the sounds s or ts instead. Also, in the Eastern dialect, the ‘intrusive h’ sound is less prominent, so that it is often omitted in phonetic spelling.

English Western Eastern
It is cold. ᎤᏴᏜ uhyvdla. ᎤᏴᏣ uyvtsa.

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

IV. Clitic -Ꮓ -hno ‘and, but’

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-04-01.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎤᏙᎯᏳᏃ ᎾᏍᏋ ᎤᎶᎩᎸ ᎪᎯ ᎤᏙᏓᏈᏗᏒᎢ.Udohiyuhno nasquv ulogilv kohi udodaquidisvi.

It has been very cloudy all day.

Write the word for ‘it was cloudy.’                            

The clitic -Ꮓ -hno is the most common clitic of transition in Cherokee, often meaning ‘**and**’ or ‘**but**.’ It can be used, to create a transition from a previous thought, or to connect clauses, phrases, or items in a series.

ᎤᏙᎯᏳ                 udohiyu                  ‘very,’ ‘really’

ᎤᏙᎯᏳᏃ               udohiyuhno           ‘and very,’ ‘and really’

 ᎣᏩᏋ, ᎨᏳᏁᎦ, ᏅᏩᏙᎯᏯᏛᏋ ᏃᎦᏛᎾ ᏂᎦᏓ ᎣᏥᏣᎳᎩ. ᏂᎯᏃ ᎤᏣᏘ ᎾᏍᏋ ᎤᏚᎩ ᎠᏋᎭ ᏙᎯᏋ ᎨᏒᎢ. ᎾᏋᏃ ᏓᏥᏲᎢᏍᏔᏂ ᎪᏪᎵᏍᎬᎢ.Owaquv, Geyunega, nvwatohiyadvquv nogadvna nigada Otsitsalagi. Nihihno utsati nasquv utugi aquvha tohiquv gesvi. Naquvhno datsiyoistani gowelisgvi.

Okay, Ge-yu-ne-ga, we Cherokees are doing fine. I have great hope that you are well also. But I will stop writing now.

And also I really like to write.

VI. Preproniminal Prefix Ꮥ- de-: Distributive or Plural Object Prefix

Read the following passage from Letter to Dollie Duncan 1951-02-20.

ᎬᏃᏓ ᏣᎳᎩ

Gvhnoda Tsalagi

Living Cherokee

 ᎤᏙᎯᏳᏋᏗᎾ ᎤᏍᏈᏯᏋ ᏓᎦᏍᎦ.Udohiyuquvdina usquiyaquv dagasga. 

It really is raining too much.

Write the word for ‘it is raining.’                              

Notice the difference among the following pair of words:

ᎠᎦᏍᎦ.                      Agasga.                             It is raining (single instance).

ᏓᎦᏍᎦ.                  Dagasga.                           It is raining (**more than once**).

ᎠᎦᏍᎦ agasga means simply that it is raining right now, and only the current instance of rainfall is being described. **ᏓᎦᏍᎦ dagasga** on the other hand means that it is raining right now and there have been other periods of rainfall observed recently in addition to the current instance. In English we can say ‘It has been raining’ to achieve a similar sense, but that does not make it clear whether or not it is also raining right now.

This prefix is called the **Distributive Prefix**, or the **Plural Object Prefix Ꮥ- de-**. Before a vowel, the prefix becomes d-.

In addition to being used to show plural instances of action, the prefix Ꮥ- de- is used to indicate a **plural direct object**.

ᎤᏅᏗ ᎠᎩᎸᏉᏗ.                  Unvdi agilvkwdi.                  I like **milk** (singular, inanimate).

ᏚᏯ ᏓᎩᎸᏉᏗ.                  Tuya dagilvkwdi.                  I like **beans** (plural, inanimate).

title: Weaving Civic Life
content:
Written by Ellen Cushman, Ben Frey, and Rachel C. Jackson

Cherokee people tell a story of ᎧᎵᏁᏚᏙ kahnanesgi, Waterspider, who brought the embers of the first fire to all the beings on the earth. Waterspider wove a bowl from her web and secured it on her back. She swam to an island where a tree had caught fire and placed tiny embers in the bowl, then returned to the shore where all the animals waited. The fire singed her and the embers burned through the bowl on her back, leaving a permanent red mark. She was hailed as the most courageous of beings. Storytelling is one of the many means for writing about and writing within cultures we will take up in this class. Storytelling serves a civic purpose: stories carry social obligation and place-based knowledge.

As with Waterspider, who wove a webbed basket to bring an ember to all beings, Cherokee basket weaving and writing of everyday life create an inner container and an outer wall– a visible face for a hidden interior life that together forms a strong basket for carrying lifeways forward. Weaving this way evokes a building up, coming together, containing, and protecting. It suggests a flexible structure created within a balancing and jointly constructed effort. Weaving also suggests how the interior is built around a central element around which we organize ourselves and insulate ourselves from outside pressures.

Cherokee baskets are double-walled. The basket's interior is woven first, with a runner moving over and under structuring reeds. When the interior wall is woven upward and outward to the desired depth, the structuring reeds are bent over the outside of the interior wall. The runner then continues over and under the structuring reeds, moving down the length of the first wall until the second exterior wall is complete. The remaining structuring reeds are tucked between the interior and exterior walls to create a firm foundation on which the basket sits.

The cover page of Cherokee Writing the Keetoowah Way is inspired by Cherokee basketry, stories, and the pages brought together in our collection. The outer and inner walls of the design evoke the weaving of Cherokee civic life throughout the pages of our collection. As pictured here in a basket woven by Lena Stick, Cherokee baskets are colorful, drawing their dyes from the plants and trees found in Cherokee homelands past and present. Bloodroot, black walnut, and buckbrush tan inspire the framing of the pages of our digital collection. The black walnut dye evokes the grounding of the collection in everyday life and the writings of the Cherokee. The buckbrush tan evokes gathering, bringing together, and building an interior and exterior life and community. The bloodroot red evokes the weaving of Waterspider's web to hold the ember brought to the animals.

title: Word Order
content:
Written by ᏗᎦᏃᏣᎵ Patrick Del Percio

ᎬᏂᎨᏒ ᎢᏯᏛᏁᎯ – Introduction

The following examples represent the simple subject – verb sentence structure:

wesa nigawe

cat – it is meowing (making a noise)

‘A cat is meowing.’

sasa naniwe

geese – they are honking

‘Some geese are honking.’

*You’ll notice that there are no articles such as ‘a/an’ or ‘some’ in Cherokee. These articles are implied in the structure of the sentence. As we will see in the examples that follow, the article na can be used to mean ‘that/the’ depending on the context of the sentence.

Typically in simple declarative statements, sentences in Cherokee take on a subject – object – verb word order. However, to reverse this structure is not always incorrect, as we will see in the following examples.

na agehya gitli agowatiha

the – woman – dog – she sees

‘The woman sees a dog.’

gitli agowatiha na agehya

dog – she sees – the – woman

‘The woman sees a dog.’

udohiyu udlvkwsati na achutsa

really – he is a braggart – the/that boy

‘The boy really is a braggart.’

Notice sentences two and three. In both examples, the subject of the sentence is placed at the end of the sentence, pulling the object into primary focus. Sentence three, the adjective udlvkwsati is made the focal point of the sentence, and then towards the end of the sentence we are given our subject – na achuja/achutsa ‘the boy’.

In The Story about a Man Named Old George Stonejug, find two good examples of sentences with a subject-object-verb word order. Write them in the lines provided below in syllabary, phonetics, and English.

Sentences Involving Adjectives

Adjectives function in various ways in Cherokee sentence structure. In the two examples below, the adjective is placed before the noun and verb yielding the following translations.

usdi gitli atlido’a

little – dog – (it) is running around

‘A little dog is running around.’

na utana yona nigawe’a

the – big – bear – (it) is growling

‘The big bear is growling.’

The next way that adjectives can be used in a sentence is by adding the adjective after a noun which gives the meaning of ‘[it] is ______.’

na tsisqua gigage’i

the – bird – it is red

‘The bird is red.’

na nvya uwodige’i

the – rock – it is brown

‘The rock is brown.’

Sentences Involving Both Adjectives and Verbs

In these examples, you will see that adverbs in Cherokee typically precede the verb and come after the noun.

na usdi gitli ayanuli atlido’a

the – little – dog – fast – (it’s) running

‘The little dog is running fast.’

na utana yona sdaya nigawe’a

the – big – bear – loud – it’s making noise

‘The big bear is growling loudly.’

Sentences Without Verbs

In the late Durbin Feeling’s Outline of Cherokee Grammar, he relates how not all sentences in Cherokee will exhibit a verb. To make this more clear, he provides the following examples to illustrate how some nouns and adjectives in Cherokee already contain a verb:

na asgaya agidoda

that – man – he is father to me

‘That man is my father.’

agidoda utana

my father – he is big

‘My father is big.’

‘To Be’

The verb ‘to be’ functions differently in Cherokee than it does in English. Many Cherokee verbs, as well as nouns, adjectives, and adverbs, already have ‘to be’ built into the word itself.

  1. 4 ᎠᎵᏱᎵᏒᎢ ᎤᏃᏴᏍᏗᎢ ᎨᏎᏍᏗ ᎢᏦᏗᏱ.

    2. ‘Burial will be toward 4:00 [p.m.] at Echota.’

    2. ‘One who is a healer must take care of himself [themselves].’

Passive Sentence Construction

Passive voice is used when the action is being done to someone or when the person doing the action is unknown. Let’s look at a few examples from Durbin Feeling’s Outline of Cherokee Grammar that demonstrate a simple example of the passive sentence structure.

asgaya atsigowhtiha

man – he is being seen

‘A man is being seen.’

vgigowhtiha

‘I am being seen.’

asgaya ugohwtiha agehya

man – she is being seen – woman

‘A woman is being seen by a man.’

Next, let’s look at some examples that can be found in the DAILP collections:

ᎠᏎᏃ ᎾᏊᏃ ᎠᎦᏎᎮᎴᎢ ᎢᎬᏩᏛᏁᏗ ᎨᏒᎢ

Asehno naquuhno agasehele’i igvwadvnhdi gesv’i

but – now – he was shown – what he could do – being

‘But then he was shown what he could do.’

ᎠᏂᏓᏪᎯ ᏥᎨᎨᏲᎲᏍᎨᎢ

Anidawehi jigegehyohvsge’i

[to be] magicians – they were taught

‘They were taught to be magicians.’

ᎠᎾᏗᏍᎪᎢ ᏧᎾᏛᏐᏅᎯ ᎤᏂᏃᎮᎸᎯ ᎨᏒ Ꮔ[Ꮝ]ᏛᎢ ᎤᏁᏲᏅᎯ

Anadisgo’i tsunatvsohnvhi unihnohelvhi gesv nu[s]dv’i unehyonvhi

they say – the elders – they told about – being – what – they were taught

‘The elders said this. They spoke of what they were taught.’

ᎤᏚᏚ ᎠᎦᏴᎵ ᎤᏓᏐᏅ[Ꮕ]Ꭿ ᎨᏎᎢ.

Ududu agayvli udasonv[nv]hi gese’i

his grandfather – ancient – [he] wounded – was

‘His grandfather was wounded.’

Sentences with Prepositions

There are few prepositions in Cherokee that function on their own. For the most part, prepositions are found intertwined in the Cherokee verb. Below are some examples of prepositions that stand on their own, drawn from Durbin Feeling’s Outline of Cherokee Grammar.

gvhdi: ‘with, using’

yonega gvhdi gawoniha

English – with – s/he is speaking

‘S/he is speaking English.’

Seli daquado’a tsalagi gvhdi

Seli – My name is – Cherokee  – using

‘My name in Cherokee is Seli.’

ganvqualosdi gvhdi gvhniha

hammer – with – s/he is hitting it

‘S/he is hitting it with a hammer.’

didla: ‘toward’

digaduhv didla ega

town – toward – s/he is going

‘S/he is going towards town.’

igvyididla: ‘in front of’

gahltsode igvyididla gadoga

house – in front of – s/he is standing

‘S/he is standing in front of the house.’

Now, let’s look at some examples from the DAILP collections:

ᏚᏂᎾᏗ ᎢᎬᏱ ᎢᎦ ᏙᏓᏉᏅᎯ ᏓᎦᏃᏴᏥ ᎢᏦᏗ ᏧᏙᏓᏂᏐᏘᏱ

Dunindi igvyi iga dodaquonvhi daganoyvtsi itsodi tsudanisodiyi

October – first – day – Monday – s/he will be buried – Echota – at the cemetary

‘Burial will be Monday [2:00 p.m.], October 1 at Echota Cemetary.’

ᎬᏍᎦᎵᏍᎩ ᏩᏯ ᎦᏥᏲᏪᎳᏏ ᎨᏈᎵ ᏓᎦᏏ

Gvsgalisgi wahya gatsiyowelasi gequili daksi

Gvsgalisgi – Wahya – I just wrote it for them – Gequili – dagsi

‘Gvsgalisgi Wahya, I, Gequili Dagsi, just wrote it for them.’

ᎢᎬᏩᏍᏗᎭᏋ ᏙᎯ ᏓᎩᎩᏨᏁᎦ

Igvwsdihaquv tohi dagigitsvhnega

Just the same – peaceful / healthy – I am going from day to day

‘I am the same, still healthy from day to day.’

ᎯᎠ ᎤᏛᎢᏍᏗ ᎤᏫᏅ ᎠᏯᎭ ᎠᏧᏣ ᎾᏍᎩᏃ ᏓᏥᏲᎱᏎᎴᎢ ᎪᎱᏍᏗ ᎤᎾᎥᎢ [ᎠᎴ ᏧᎬᏩᎶᏗ ᏄᏩᎾᏅ]

Hi’a utv’isdi uwinv ayaha atsutsa nasgihno datsiyohusele’i gohusdi una’v’i [ale tsugvwahldi nuwananv]

This – old man – Young man – he is in [here] – boy – and that – it was left to him – something – he had

‘This old man left his belongings to a young man in here. [that is, all his valuables.]’

ᎪᏪᎵᏋ ᎬᏗ ᎠᏴ ᎠᎹ ᎥᏉᏪᎳᏏ ᏄᏍᏛᏋ ᏂᏥᏪᏍᎬᎢ

Gohweliquv gvhdi ayv ama vquohwelasi nusdvquv nitsiwesgv’i

Letter – by – I – Ama – he wrote it for me – just what – I was saying

‘This was written for me, Ama, just as I said.’

ᎢᏧᎳ ᎣᎩᎾᏅᏔ ᏄᏍᏛ ᏄᏩᏅ ᎾᏍᎩ ᎪᏪᎵ

Ursula oginanta nusdv nuwanv nasgi gohweli

Both – another and I know – what – she had it [in] – that – letter

‘We both know what was in the letter.’
